intro: Pedicularis procumbens, commonly known as the creeping lousewort, is a flowering plant native to alpine and subalpine regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, characterized by its parasitic nature and lack of chlorophyll. The plant produces striking, spurred flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red, typically blooming in late summer. Its stems are prostrate, often growing along the ground, and it has small, alternate leaves. Pedicularis procumbens thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and tundra environments.
